Theme and IGIF Introduction

From intent to execution: Building momentum for India's climate solutions

The India Green Investment Forum (IGIF), hosted by the Impact Investors Council (IIC), returns at a moment when green finance in India is shifting from intent to execution. The ecosystem is no longer testing ideas — it's scaling them. IGIF 2025 is where momentum builds, connections deepen, and investment flows accelerate.

This year's theme, "Scaling India's Climate Solutions: Building for the World," reflects India's readiness to lead with solutions rooted in innovation, sustainability, and inclusion.

India now boasts a growing pipeline of climate-first enterprises, supportive policies, and institutional investors prepared to back scale-ready models. With catalytic capital already in motion and operational models taking shape across sectors, the conversation is no longer "why" or "when" but "how fast" and "how far."

ABOUT THE FORUM

India Green Investment Forum

The India Green Investment Forum (IGIF) returns with its second edition at a time when green finance in India is no longer in pilot mode. From proof-of-concept to proof-of-scale, the market is shifting and IGIF is where the action converges.

Hosted by the Impact Investors Council, IGIF 2025 is the country’s definitive convening on climate finance bringing together policymakers, global investors, development institutions, philanthropies, financial intermediaries, and climate-first enterprises. This isn’t just a gathering, it’s a gearshift. IGIF 2025 is designed for momentum: sharp plenaries, sector deep-dives, investor dialogues, and curated LP-GP engagements. Every session is built to spark collaboration, mobilise investment, and push green solutions to scale.

The forum reflects a deeper truth: green capital in India has arrived. The ecosystem is maturing, infrastructure is building, and the case for climate investments is stronger than ever. What’s needed now is speed, connection, and execution

Critical Themes for IGIF 2025

IGIF 2025 spotlights six pivotal themes that are reshaping India's climate finance landscape. Each theme represents a critical intersection of opportunity, innovation, and investment potential.

India's Leadership in Climate Innovation & Global Impact

Spotlighting India's role as a pioneer in scalable climate solutions. Explore how India's climate strategy can guide emerging economies and inspire global action.

Scaling Climate Innovations: Infrastructure, Ecosystem & Consumerism

Exploring the enabling conditions required to expand green innovation—from robust infrastructure to sustainable consumption and industrial decarbonization.

Financing the Green Transition: Capital, Risk & Innovation

Exploring innovative financial instruments and investment strategies to accelerate the transition to a sustainable economy.

Moving the Needle: Policy & Regulatory Landscape

Examining how policy frameworks and regulatory environments can catalyze or hinder climate innovation and sustainable development.

Inclusive Green Growth: Empowering Small & Marginal Stakeholders

Ensuring that the benefits of green economic transition reach all segments of society, particularly vulnerable and marginalized communities.

Emerging Subsector Deep Dives

Exploring emerging subsectors within the climate innovation landscape that offer promising investment opportunities and impact potential.

THEMATIC FOCUS AREAS

What's In It For You at IGIF 2025

Join us to experience the definitive convening on climate finance in India

Discover Actionable Insights

Dive into cutting-edge conversations around inclusive innovation, digital public infrastructure, climate-tech, gender equity, and more. Learn from policymakers, founders, funders, and ecosystem leaders shaping the future of impact in India and beyond.

Examining the Capital Stack in Depth

Take part in concentrated sessions that break down capital instruments such as grants, debt, equity, blended financing, and catalytic capital across the risk-return spectrum. Collaboratively help shape investment thesis around emerging sectors and segments, grounded in real-world case studies and market insights.

Tap into India's Next Frontier Markets

Uncover early signals and emerging sectors poised for transformative impact - climate-resilient infrastructure, circular economy, emerging new sectors and more. Get ahead of the curve by identifying the next wave of investable opportunities.

Build Collective Momentum for Systems Change

Engage with change agents committed to reshaping how India solves for its biggest challenges at scale and at speed. Through shared visioning and coalition-building, move beyond silos to architect systems-level change.

  6. Plenary 1 - Celebrating The India Climate Scale Story: Investors at the Forefront

    October 30, 2025 • 10:30 AM - 11:15 AM

    About this Session

    As the inaugural session of the India Green Investment Forum, this conversation will spotlight the visionaries who have been at the forefront of climate investing in India. These industry leaders- early pioneers in backing transformative climate solutions-will reflect on how the investment landscape has evolved, the models and innovations that have stood the test of time, and the role of policy in shaping opportunities. Beyond celebrating past milestones, the session will chart the path ahead: how climate entrepreneurs and investors together can unlock scale, accelerate impact, and position India’s innovations to inspire and serve other global markets.

  7. India Green Opportunities Report (IIC + CPI Report Launch)

    October 30, 2025 • 11:15 AM - 11:45 AM

    About this Session

    Green Investment Opportunities in India – 2025 Update

    The Impact Investors Council (IIC), in collaboration with the Climate Policy Initiative (CPI), will launch the "Green Investment Opportunities in India – 2025 Update" at the upcoming India Green Investment Forum.

    This report builds upon the 2023 edition by identifying near-term investment opportunities over a three to five-year horizon. These opportunities combine high climate impact with significant economic potential, yet currently attract limited funding. The analysis extends beyond mitigation to include resilience-focused sectors such as water, climate-smart agriculture, and cooling, in addition to clean energy and other green growth areas.

    Developed through a comprehensive literature review, stakeholder consultations, and data analysis, the report outlines sectoral opportunities across various value chains. It is supported by relevant case studies and actionable recommendations, and it proposes pathways for mobilizing private capital through policy, financial instruments, and ecosystem enablers.

    The 2025 update aims to inform investors, policymakers, and market participants on priority areas for channeling capital to support India's transition to a low-carbon, climate-resilient economy.

  10. Plenary 2 - LP Perspectives: Tapping Diverse Capital Sources to Drive India's Climate Story

    October 30, 2025 • 12:30 PM - 01:15 PM

    About this Session

    India’s climate ambitions cannot be met without bold capital at scale-yet mobilizing diverse LP sources remains one of the sector’s biggest bottlenecks. While development finance institutions and philanthropic investors have played a catalytic role, the participation of mainstream commercial capital, pension funds, insurers, and large family offices is still limited. This session will challenge leading LPs to share what it will take for them to lean in more decisively: the risk-return profiles they seek, the structures and track records they expect, and the enabling policies that could unlock their participation. The discussion will also probe the uncomfortable questions-are climate funds speaking the language LPs want to hear, are capital pools siloed rather than blended, and what must change if India is to position itself not just as an emerging opportunity, but as a global leader in climate investing at scale.

    Featured Speakers

  13. Plenary 3 - How Have Debt Underwriting Mechanisms Evolved for Funding Climate Innovation

    October 30, 2025 • 02:30 PM - 03:30 PM

    About this Session

    IIC research highlights a growing shift-climate innovators in India are increasingly turning to debt to power their growth journeys. While equity capital remains critical for early experimentation and proving market readiness, it is debt that enables scale once product-market fit is achieved. Yet, most climate business models are still unfamiliar to traditional lenders, often viewed through a high-risk lens. This session will bring together leading debt providers to unpack how underwriting approaches are evolving to serve climate entrepreneurs, the structural barriers that keep many high-impact ventures “debt-unready,” and the innovative strategies needed to bridge this financing gap. The conversation will shed light on what it takes to make debt a catalytic force in accelerating India’s climate transition.

    Featured Speakers

  14. Plenary 4 - Thematic Deepdive: Climate Smart Agriculture

    October 30, 2025 • 03:30 PM - 04:30 PM

    Introduction & Overview

    [Brief description of the case study and key insights to be shared]

    Suryanshu Hooda

    Analyst, Climate Policy Initiative

    About this Session

    Climate-smart agriculture offers pathways to build resilience for smallholder farmers, enhance soil health and lower emissions. This session will explore the investment pathways in areas like agri biotech, cold chain and post-harvest storage, precision agriculture as well as newer themes like soil carbon capture and precision agriculture. As digital innovation, and financing models can unlock scalable, investable solutions for the agri-food system with a farmer-focused approach and livelihood considerations. With digital platforms, ag-biologicals, and agri-insurance models beginning to scale, this session will ask how financiers and innovators see the path to investability in CSA.

    Discussion will cover:

    1. 1. Investment activity in biotech, precision agriculture, post-harvest storage and soil carbon solutions.
    2. 2. On-ground challenges in scaling parametric insurance and farmer-focused innovations; mitigants that could potentially address the hurdles faced.
    3. 3. The imperative to develop a design thinking approach in the building of innovative financing models centred around a farmer-focused approach and livelihood considerations.
    4. 4. Even as innovative technologies come up, how could financiers and enterprises maintain a balance between driving business scale as well as climate impact.
    5. 5. What would it take for CSA to scale and work for smallholders, going beyond bespoke pilot projects.
    6. 6. Exploring success stories that have demonstrated CSA as a frontier investment area balancing productivity, resilience, and emissions reduction.

    Featured Speakers

    PS

    Emmanuel Murray

    Investment Director, Caspian

    PS

    Neha Khanna

    Associate Director, Climate Policy Initiative

    PS

    Reihem Roy

  16. Plenary 5 - Thematic Deepdive: Energy and Feedstock Transformation

    October 30, 2025 • 05:00 PM - 06:00 PM

    Introduction & Overview

    [Brief description of the case study and key insights to be shared]

    Jaspreet Kaur

    Analyst, Climate Policy Initiative

    About this Session

    As India accelerates its clean energy transition, questions remain on how different technologies and business models will come together to shape the future of energy. From battery storage and green hydrogen to evolving feedstock strategies and flexible power systems, this session will explore how investors are viewing opportunities and risks across the spectrum.

    Discussion will explore:

    1. 1. As policy momentum accelerating energy transformation, how is private capital placed to develop a focused investment thesis around emerging spaces in green hydrogen, battery energy storage and other energy transformation levers.
    2. 2. What do investors seek to drive long-term capital into these areas.
    3. 3. Is financial innovation the need of the hour? What kind of structures could move the needle and aid in market building of upcoming innovations?
    4. 4. As the deep-tech wave emerges, how is the investment pipeline shaping up? What do potential investors need to bear in mind, to build a deep-tech expertise in asset-heavy energy innovations.
    5. 5. Where can India realistically build competitiveness in the global energy value chain.

  4. Plenary 6 - Global Perspectives on Emerging Mitigation and Adaptation Investments: Lessons for India

    October 31, 2025 • 10:15 AM - 11:00 AM

    About this Session

    India’s climate investments in the past decade have largely focused on renewable energy capacities and electric mobility. The country’s climate interventions need to go beyond these two areas, into emerging areas of mitigation and decarbonization, and climate adaptation, which have so far only witnessed a trickle of capital flows. India needs to attract more climate finance to scale its climate interventions beyond these two areas, especially from private finance sources. This session presents research by Climake and the UK’s Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office (FCDO) on how global climate funds have invested in emerging mitigation and adaptation segments, and the lessons that funds and LPs focused on India can draw as they start to focus on opportunities present in these nascent areas.The panel discussion during this session will also feature GPs and LPs who have already built conviction in these segments, sharing their views on investing in emerging areas of climate action, and what the wider private finance ecosystem needs for more capital to go towards these segments.

    Featured Speakers

  7. Plenary 7 - Unlocking Investor Action for a Just Industrial Transition in India

    October 31, 2025 • 11:30 AM - 12:15 PM

    About this Session

    India’s industrial transformation is critical for its climate ambitions-but it must also be just, inclusive, and equitable. This session will explore how investors can play a catalytic role in supporting industries to decarbonize while safeguarding jobs, communities, and livelihoods. Leaders from finance and industry will discuss the challenges and opportunities in funding low-carbon industrial pathways, the innovative business models that balance profitability with social impact, and the tools investors can use to drive accountability and systemic change. The conversation will highlight how strategic capital deployment can ensure that India’s industrial transition is not only sustainable but also socially responsible-setting a blueprint for inclusive climate action globally.

  10. Plenary 8 - Blended Finance for Climate Action: Leveraging Innovative Financing Mechanisms

    October 31, 2025 • 12:30 PM - 01:30 PM

    Case Study Presentation

    Case Study Presentation

    [Brief description of the case study and key insights to be shared]

    Sruthi Ramesh

    Investment Consultant, Good Fashion Fund

    About this Session

    Closing India’s climate finance gap will require capital that is not just plentiful, but also patient, risk-tolerant, and innovative. Blended finance has emerged as a powerful tool to unlock this capital—bringing together concessional, philanthropic, and commercial sources to fund climate solutions that would otherwise struggle to scale. This session will explore cutting-edge structures and instruments-from first-loss guarantees and results-based financing to carbon markets and platform approaches-that are reshaping the landscape. Investors and practitioners will share what has worked (and what hasn’t), the barriers that still prevent blended finance from moving from pilot to mainstream, and how India can position itself as a global leader in mobilizing blended capital for climate action.

  13. Plenary 9 - Thematic Deepdive: Li-ion Battery Recycling

    October 31, 2025 • 02:30 PM - 03:30 PM

    Introduction & Overview

    [Brief description of the case study and key insights to be shared]

    Sagnik Chakraborty

    Manager, Climate Policy Initiative

    About this Session

    As EV adoption surges, and waste management grows as an environmental need, battery recycling is becoming central to supply chain security and the circular economy. Battery recycling and second-life applications represent a strategic opportunity at the intersection of critical mineral security, resource efficiency, and circular economy innovation. However, is this the next wave of climate investment, or a space still searching for scalable models? This session will examine how investors, entrepreneurs, and policymakers are approaching the economics, risks, and global positioning of India's recycling industry.

    Discussion will cover:

    1. 1. Is the LiB recycling space matching the pace that the EV growth merits? How can investors capitalise on this emerging space, whilst also addressing technology and supply chain risks?
    2. 2. What are the emerging business models across battery waste collection, processing, and second-life applications, that hold immediate promise?
    3. 3. The role of EPR and regulatory frameworks in shaping investor confidence; what do investors really seek?
    4. 4. What do potential investors need to bear in mind while investing in LiB recycling?
    5. 5. How can financial innovation drive and position India's as a global leader in battery circularity?

    Featured Speakers

    PS

    Gaurav Gupta

    Head of Corporate Finance, Attero

    PS

    Jai Shah

    Associate Director, Climate Policy Initiative

    PS

    Vasudha Madhavan

    Founder & CEO, Ostara Advisors

    PS

    Vipul Patel

    Partner, Seed Investing, IIMA Ventures

    PS

    Janavi Papriwal

    Assoiciate Partner, South Asia, Circulate Capital

  14. Plenary 10 - Thematic Deepdive: Sustainable Cooling & Heat Resilience

    October 31, 2025 • 03:30 PM - 04:30 PM

    Introduction & Overview

    [Brief description of the case study and key insights to be shared]

    Bhavye Ananad

    Research Associate, Impact Investors Council

    [Brief description of the case study and key insights to be shared]

    Meghaa Gangahar

    Senior Analyst, Climate Policy Initiative

    About this Session

    Rising heat and soaring demand for cooling present India with both a resilience challenge and a climate opportunity. Yet questions remain on the scale of demand, affordability, and the right models for investment. This session will look at how financiers and innovators view cooling as a frontier sector, and whether resilience-focused solutions can attract capital at scale.

    The discussion aims to cover:

    1. 1. Cooling as both a development necessity and an investment frontier – why did this space take so long to emerge as a potential investment opportunity?
    2. 2. The landscape of cooling solutions in India – what seems to be working? And what does not?
    3. 3. Exploring the viability of business model innovations such as Cooling-as-a-Service, cold-chain-as-a-service, and community-level cooling.
    4. 4. How could investors develop a cooling-based investment strategy? Do we look at sector-focused initiatives or a sector-agnostic one?
    5. 5. The role of policy frameworks like ICAP, efficiency standards, and subnational initiatives as investment catalysts.
    6. 6. The role of financial innovation to address heat resilience for heat-stressed regions.

    Featured Speakers

    PS

    Benjamin Hickman

    Programme Manager, Climate Change Division, UNEP India

What People Say About IGIF

Hear from pioneers, leaders and partners about their IGIF experience

The UK is proud to partner with India in advancing impact investing that delivers real change. Industry bodies like IIIC and their forums like India Green Investment Forum have emerged as leading platforms to convene diverse voices and engage entrepreneurs, investors and policy makers on green finance and climate action. Guided by the UK-India Vision 2035, we value our continued partnership to unlock scalable solutions for inclusive growth, aiming to create a world free from poverty on a liveable planet.

SW

Gaurav Kapoor

Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office

IIC’s role in strengthening India’s climate investment landscape is both significant and inspiring. Forums like IGIF and Prabhav stand out for turning conversations into concrete action. IGIF 2023 was especially important for spotlighting investible, early-stage climate innovations and convening investors, policymakers and entrepreneurs capable of accelerating their success.

SW

Sandiip Bhammer

Green Frontier Capital

IGIF, along with the biannual Prabhav, has played a valuable role in spotlighting India’s unique strengths in climate innovation and connecting not only the Indian stakeholders, but allowed for interactions with global capital providers. As an impact investor, community/ecosystem builder and global connector, and being a long-term supporter, I’ve seen firsthand how the forum creates meaningful dialogue between investors, entrepreneurs, and policymakers, moving beyond rhetoric to concrete, investible opportunities.

What sets events such as IGIF apart is its ability to bridge the differences in goals for stakeholder groups, and synthesize an agenda which appeals to all, and naturally showcases opportunities to work together. The ability to build relationships across all stakeholder groups and then follow up and explore meaningful synergistic opportunities are why I will continue to support, attend and participate (as I can) in IGIF because they bring stakeholder groups together, which does enhance momentum for climate change in the country, and does so in a relevant, thoughtful manner.

ABOUT IIC

The Impact Investors Council (IIC)

India's pre-eminent member-based organization for Impact Investing

The Impact Investors Council (IIC) is India's pre-eminent member-based, not-for-profit industry body set up to strengthen Impact Investing in the country. IIC's key areas of focus include evangelizing the India impact story to investors, government advocacy & leveraging research based thought-leadership to support the growth of the sector.

We are supported by 60+ members and ecosystem partners including The Rockefeller Foundation, British International Investment, Michael and Susan Dell Foundation, Elevar Equity, Leapfrog Investments, Omnivore, Asha Ventures,Lok Capital, Grameen Capital, Acumen, Vivriti Assest Manangement among others.

IGIF 2025 is proudly supported by these leading organizations committed to advancing climate innovation and sustainable finance in India.

    4. Plenary 6 - Navigating the Policy Landscape for Green Transitions & DFI Investments

      Navigating the Policy Landscape for Green Transitions & DFI Investments

      10:15 - 11:00 am

      Plenary 6 - Navigating the Policy Landscape for Green Transitions & DFI Investments

      October 31, 2025 • 10:15 AM - 11:00 AM

      About this Session

      Policy will make or break India’s green transition and development finance institutions (DFIs) are uniquely positioned to bridge the gap between ambition and action. This session will unpack how evolving policies on energy, mobility, agriculture, and carbon markets are shaping investment opportunities, while also spotlighting the bottlenecks that continue to deter private capital. Leading DFIs and policymakers will share how they are navigating risks, structuring investments, and aligning global climate goals with India’s development priorities. The discussion will probe tough questions: Are current policies investment-grade? How can DFIs play a catalytic role in de-risking and crowding in commercial capital? And what shifts are needed to ensure India’s policy landscape accelerates, rather than constrains, its green transition.

      Featured Speakers

      PS

      Dr. Priya Sharma

      Head of Sustainable Finance, Green Investment Bank

      RM

      Rajiv Mehta

      Founder & CEO, ClimateScale Ventures
